ST ATEMENT
 
OF
 
INTENT
 
NKWOR
 
JANE
 
CHINELO
 
 
I
 
aim
 
to
 
develop
 
reinforcement
 
learning
 
methods
 
that
 
learn
 
efficiently
 
from
 
sparse,
 
noisy ,
 
or
 
delayed
 
feedback
 
and
 
generalise
 
reliably
 
across
 
real-world
 
environments.
 
This
 
research
 
direction
 
emer ged
 
from
 
an
 
unexpected
 
path:
 
during
 
a
 
2018
 
university
 
strike,
 
I
 
enrolled
 
in
 
a
 
programming
 
school
 
and
 
discovered
 
a
 
deep
 
fascination
 
with
 
how
 
systems
 
represent
 
information,
 
make
 
decisions,
 
and
 
adapt
 
to
 
uncertain
 
environments
 
–
 
a
 
curiosity
 
that
 
has
 
since
 
crystallised
 
into
 
this
 
focused
 
research
 
ambition.
 
This
 
ambition
 
crystallised
 
during
 
my
 
master ’s
 
dissertation,
 
Development
 
of
 
an
 
Autonomous
 
Agent
 
for
 
a
 
Number
 
Strategy
 
Game
 
Using
 
Deep
 
Q-Networks
.
 
Motivated
 
by
 
an
 
interest
 
in
 
how
 
systems—biological
 
or
 
artificial—learn
 
under
 
uncertainty ,
 
I
 
developed
 
a
 
DQN-based
 
agent
 
augmented
 
with
 
Prioritised
 
Experience
 
Replay .
 
I
 
trained
 
and
 
evaluated
 
the
 
agent
 
across
 
thousands
 
of
 
episodes,
 
comparing
 
its
 
performance
 
to
 
deterministic
 
baselines
 
such
 
as
 
Minimax
 
and
 
Reservoir
 
Sampling.
 
The
 
DQN
 
achieved
 
an
 
over
 
85%
 
success
 
rate
 
by
 
generalising
 
from
 
experience
 
rather
 
than
 
relying
 
on
 
exhaustive
 
computation
 
–
 
findings
 
I
 
have
 
documented
 
in
 
a
 
manuscript
 
currently
 
under
 
review
 
and
 
a
 
conference
 
paper
 
accepted
 
for
 
presentation
 
in
 
2025.
 
The
 
work
 
was
 
technically
 
demanding:
 
I
 
confronted
 
vanishing
 
rewards,
 
unstable
 
training
 
dynamics,
 
and
 
sensitivity
 
to
 
hyperparameters.
 
Overcoming
 
these
 
challenges
 
required
 
designing
 
custom
 
reward-shaping
 
strategies,
 
adjusting
 
network
 
architectures,
 
and
 
experimenting
 
with
 
exploration
 
schedules
 
to
 
optimise
 
performance.
 
More
 
importantly ,
 
the
 
project
 
revealed
 
deeper
 
limitations
 
with
 
standard
 
DQN
 
methods—overestimation
 
bias,
 
poor
 
sample
 
efficiency ,
 
and
 
fragility
 
in
 
high-dimensional
 
settings.
 
These
 
gaps
 
highlight
 
a
 
central
 
challenge:
 
deploying
 
RL
 
agents
 
in
 
real-world
 
environments
 
requires
 
learning
 
from
 
imperfect

2
 
signals
 
(sparse

delays),

(transfer
 
learning),
 
and

so
 
safely
 
(robustness,
 
trustworthiness).
 
My
 
doctoral
 
research
 
will
 
address
 
these
 
interconnected
 
challenges.
 
My
 
interdisciplinary
 
work
 
as
 
a
 
Technical
 
Assistant
 
on
 
a
 
grant-funded
 
Thought
 
Management
 
Therapy
 
project
 
deepened
 
my
 
interest
 
in
 
human-centred
 
AI.
 
Supporting
 
the
 
development
 
of
 
digital
 
psychological
 
assessment
 
tools
 
and
 
conducting
 
statistical
 
analyses
 
exposed
 
me
 
to
 
how
 
human
 
cognition,
 
behavioural
 
patterns,
 
and
 
mental
 
workload
 
shape
 
real-world
 
interactions
 
with
 
intelligent
 
systems.
 
This
 
experience
 
strengthened
 
my
 
commitment
 
to
 
designing
 
autonomous
 
agents
 
that
 
are
 
not
 
only
 
technically
 
powerful
 
but
 
responsive
 
to
 
human
 
needs,
 
constraints,
 
and
 
expectations.
 
A
 
similar
 
insight
 
emer ged
 
when
 
I
 
built
 
a
 
RAG-powered
 
business
 
assistant
 
using
 
LLMs,
 
where
 
the
 
challenge
 
of
 
translating
 
complex
 
regulatory
 
information
 
into
 
actionable
 
guidance
 
highlighted
 
the
 
importance
 
of
 
grounding
 
intelligent
 
systems
 
in
 
explicit
 
representations,
 
practical
 
constraints,
 
and
 
real
 
user
 
contexts.
 
Across
 
my
 
experiences
 
in
 
reinforcement
 
learning,
 
language
 
modelling,
 
and
 
psychological
 
assessment,
 
I
 
have
 
come
 
to

that

systems

representation
 
learning
 
and

research
 
teaches
 
me

and

with

systems.

experiences
 
shape
 
my

of

agents

are
 
not
 
only

but
 
aligned
 
with

realities.

in
